urn:contentItem:5Y3H-RT71-F0J6-J2CT-00000-00Langi Ghiran fire close to culturally significant Indigenous site2020-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:06:45ZLexisNexisLangi Ghiran fire close to culturally significant Indigenous siteEliza Berlage

A small bushfire in Langi Ghiran State Park near Warrak on Wednesday afternoon was close to a culturally significant Indigenous site.

Country Fire Authority District 16 operations officer Neville Collins said CFA crews initially responded to the one hectare fire at Lagoon Track before handing it to Forest Fire Management Victoria.

"We were on site when we were advised that there was some culturally significant sites near the fire," he said.

Mr Collins said Parks Victoria staff were called to ensure they knew where the Indigenous scar trees and rock art were before using bulldozers and waterbombing aircraft to bring the fire under control.

"The fire was small, only one hectare in size," he said.

READ MORE: Langi Ghiran State Park bushfires under control, smoke advice for Ararat and surrounding towns

Mr Collins said the cause of the fire was still under investigation.

A smoke advice warning remains in place for Ararat, Bayindeen, Buangor, Dobie, Warrak.

Langi Ghiran State Park is twenty minutes east of Ararat.

urn:contentItem:617W-DDP1-JD34-V1TR-00000-00Expect smoke: planned burns underway while weather calms2020-11-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:06:45ZLexisNexisExpect smoke: planned burns underway while weather calms

A planned burning program is expected to take place over the weekend and coming days as long as conditions are favourable, authorities say

Forest Fire Management Victoria plan to start its spring planned burning across the Midlands Fire District. including around Ballarat, Smythesdale, Daylesford-Hepburn Springs, Blackwood, Macedon, Brisbane Ranges and Mount Lonarch.

"Planned burning is a vital part of the work that FFMVic and our partner agencies do to reduce the size, intensity and impact of bushfires on our communities and the environment, " Deputy Chief Fire Officer, Tony English said in a statement.

"Without planned burning and other fuel management work like clearing, mowing and slashing, bushfires will be bigger and harder for our firefighters to control, so we're taking every opportunity to burn while conditions allow, and it's safe to do so.

"The periods of cooler weather in spring and autumn are the most suitable and safest for us to carry out our planned burning operations - they can only go ahead when the weather and conditions allow.

"The spring program is generally smaller than in autumn as the weather can be more variable and we focus on smaller, strategic community protection burns.

"When conditions are suitable for burning, communities may see and smell smoke, and some roads and forest areas may need to be closed for public safety."

"We understand that smoke from planned burns can cause concern, but we are taking every opportunity to burn while conditions allow and it so safe to do so, while monitoring smoke impacts."

All FFMVic crews are adhering to appropriate public health and hygiene guidelines to ensure operations can safely continue across the state.

Under the current public health advice, our planned burning program can continue for now. If that advice changes, we will make any adjustments necessary in consultation with Victorian Department of Health & Human Services, Environment Protection Authority Victoria, CFA (Country Fire Authority) and Vic Emergency.

To find out when and where planned burns are happening near you go to www.vic.gov.au/plannedburns or call 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:63MM-2251-JD34-V3WT-00000-00Council candidates throw support behind campaign to save Dalmeny forest2021-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:06:45ZLexisNexisCouncil candidates throw support behind campaign to save Dalmeny forestDalmeny Matters

Council candidates for the upcoming local elections have thrown their support behind a community group's campaign to stop the sale of 40 hectares of land in Dalmeny.

Dalmeny Matters has been campaigning against the council's sale of the land near Tatiara Street since it was finalised in a council meeting in July.

The group has claimed the decision to sell the land was "rushed through", and also cites council's website which says Dalmeny is not suitable for affordable housing.

Dalmeny Matters also recently found evidence of activity by the yellow-bellied glider on the land.

READ MORE: Pawpaw inspires a lifetime of proud gardening for Narooma's Brian Tilley

In a recently published article about the forest, a spokesman for The Mayne Team questioned the council's decision.

"The questions that remain unanswered are: why was the sale of bushland to be cleared for housing rushed through, and why can't new housing be on cleared land in or near existing towns?" the article read.

"Rather than selling the forest, Eurobodalla Shire Council could rezone the land to community use allowing Dalmeny residents to continue to enjoy the bushland while the wildlife refuge and habitat remains.

"The Mayne Team is absolutely committed to the protection of wildlife and their habitats, and this applies as much to Dalmeny as it applies to the rest of the Eurobodalla.

"The large forest in Dalmeny is in good condition, a refuge to bird and animal life, and Dalmeny residents say they value the forest and want to keep it there for all to enjoy."

Eurobodalla Labor's David Grace was also critical of the decision in a statement provided to Dalmeny Matters.

"The Labor team has supported the Dalmeny community's concerns about this development from the time it was brought before the council," he said.

READ MORE: Four new COVID-19 cases in the Eurobodalla, Batemans Bay cluster tally rises to 10

"We are strongly of the view that although development is necessary in the Shire, it needs to be carried out to at least maintain, and preferably improve, the environment in which we live.

"This includes ensuring that species other than humans can also enjoy this beautiful part of the world.

"We support further study of this area to ensure than any developments will not adversely affect yellow-bellied gliders or other threatened species, and we will take whatever action is needed to ensure the council meets its obligations to protect the species, as detailed in the Eurobodalla Settlement Strategy."

Advance Eurobodalla's mayoral candidate Mat Hatcher also expressed his desire to protect the plot of land.

"Given AE's environmental policies, we are committed to protecting the habitat in question," he said.

"Environmentally responsible and sustainable housing and other development is what AE is about.

"We also note NSW Minister for Planning, Rob Stokes, is strongly opposed to the proposed Dalmeny development."

Eurobodalla Greens candidate Alison Worthington expressed her "full support" of Dalmeny Matters' campaign.

"We will continue the support shown by Greens Councillor McGinlay who arranged, at very short notice, the initial community meeting that was the catalyst for the formation of the Dalmeny Matters group," she said.

READ MORE: Bushfire Inquiry told Belowra man Colin Burns died in Badja Forest Fire after late decision to evacuate

"We will ensure that the need to protect this habitat for yellow-bellied gliders and glossy black cockatoos, as evidence by the observations of the local community, is taken seriously.

"The Greens maintain that no biodiversity offset is capable of reducing the impact of the loss of threatened species - we simply must do everything we can to protect their existing habitat in its place."

urn:contentItem:60T3-B1B1-F0J6-J2CF-00000-00Cause of blaze in shed unclear2020-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:06:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Cause of blaze in shed unclearSandy Powell

The cause of a fire which tore through a Circular Head warehouse remains unknown.

Millions of dollars worth of property was destroyed in the blaze which was first reported to authorities about 3am Wednesday.

The shed on Mengha Road is understood to have contained property belonging to several different businesses, including mining companies.

Tasmania Fire Service acting Arthur District Officer Tony Wood said it may be days before the investigation into the blaze is completed.

A cause had not been identified as of Wednesday afternoon, and it was therefore not yet being treated as suspicious.

About 12 hours after the blaze was reported, fire crews were still working to extinguish seeds of fire underneath the debris.

The shed owner and Mr Wood were quick to heap praise on the quick response from fire crews.

"It was very serious at the beginning, the fire was extremely intense," Mr Wood said.

"But the first arriving fire brigades have done a fantastic job."

Fire crews from Forest, Smithton, Stanley, Irishtown, Boat Harbour, Burnie and Devonport all attended the blaze.

Mr Wood said firefighters identified there was a caretaker living on site asleep at the time, who was then woken up and taken to safety.

"This is extremely crucial [work] because there is a possibility somebody could have died if that person wasn't identified and woken up.

"And a large amount of high quality goods has been salvaged and still can be used by business."

The owner of the building said it was "incredible" how quickly the volunteer fire crews, particularly from Forest, were able to attend the blaze and begin fighting the fire.

"They were notified at 2.57am and there was someone on site here, within eight minutes from Forest fire department," the owner said.

"It's pretty incredible. Hats off to them and we really appreciate that."

urn:contentItem:6418-DKX1-F0J6-J068-00000-00Riveting and raw look at bushfires2021-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:06:45ZLexisNexisNONEPg. 22Riveting and raw look at bushfiresJane Freebury

A Fire Inside. M, 92 minutes. Four stars.

Volunteering in this country is strong. We saw how it boosted the Sydney Olympics. Two decades later the Australian volunteering public was called on to do more, and then some, during the incredibly testing conditions of the Black Summer of 2019-2020. From south-east Queensland to the Southern Highlands and Far South Coast of NSW, to eastern Victoria, volunteering took on a whole new meaning.

This is a documentary about the men and women of the NSW Rural Fire Service and the communities they risked their lives for during the hellish nightmare that unfolded two years ago. NSWRFS is one of the largest volunteer fire-fighting organisations in the world and, as former Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons points out, 90 percent of the RFS are volunteers and most people have no idea that their work is unpaid.

It's what these firies do. When they are needed, they down tools in jobs in the public service, or retail or design consultancy to don hi-vis gear, jump into emergency services vehicles and head towards the fire front. Most people run away from bushfire, observes Brendon O'Connor of Balmoral Village RFS in the Southern Highlands, while the RFS runs towards it.

O'Connor, who was formerly in the military, is one of two key witnesses whose story shapes this riveting documentary. Nathan Barnden of Jellat Jellat RFS is the other key witness. Both men were traumatised by their experiences, had near-death experiences and are now transitioning to recovery. Volunteering day after day in a constant state of high alert, where survival is touch-and-go, has an inevitable human cost.

On the night in the Southern Highlands when two young firefighters lost their lives, O'Connor, a captain in the RFS, refused to leave Balmoral Village unattended as instructed. Conditions were extremely volatile after three years of drought throughout Australia's south-east, but he stayed on, as many did in fact, throughout the regions, taking enormous risks to save lives and property.

It's Barnden's remarkable, harrowing personal story that helps structure the narrative. It began when the Badja Forest fire burst out of the mountains and sprinted across the tinder-dry dairy country of the Bega Valley towards the coast.

Barnden and a fellow firefighter, answering a call to 000 from Quaama, jumped into a 4WD without any fire-safe features, the only vehicle available, and drove through fireground to the house. A family of seven were huddled together inside under a blanket with three-quarters of the building alight around them. After the men had managed to drive them out to safety, with minutes to spare, they risked their lives to save several more families within the hour. It was the night that Barnden's uncle and cousin in nearby Wandella were killed by a fireball as they tried to defend their property.

Despite the family tragedy, he continued working for the RFS, non-stop without a moment to grieve, for the next two months. Unsurprisingly, he is still carrying a burden of guilt about not being there for his uncle and cousin.

It is still overwhelming to see those images of tiny figures in silhouette in the foreground of towering walls of flame. When day turned to night on New Year 2020, I was with my family sheltering in Bermagui surf club while fire tore through our block south of Cobargo.

The apocalyptic vision from eastern Australia that summer shocked the world and the smoke drifted across the globe. At the end of it all, when rain suddenly fell, there had been 200 consecutive days of emergencies and an area similar in size to Britain was burnt out.

Directed in workmanlike fashion by Justin Krook, with assistance from Luke Mazzaferro, A Fire Inside tells it how it was, and how it is now. The second half of the doco is devoted to mental health, food charities and to building community resilience, the area to which Fitzsimmons has made a natural segue from his former role.

There is little need for embellishment with raw, unfiltered human content such as this, still so extraordinary and riveting for us all. I hope it's being screened at Capital Hill.
